body.p:
Very honored Sir, I certainly do not want would not
be compelled you, dear sir, to be burdened with this
letter, had I not heard from many people of your
straight forwardness and true humanitarianism as
you spread it before the masses fully exemplify it in
your preaching. That is what encouraged me to write.
I, therefore, presume to rely upon your good under-
standing and your subsequent conviction and present
to you my most humble request. I want to do so
as briefly as possible and not burden you with many
words and therefore this is my story:

About five years ago I was forced by misfortune
to leave my fatherland, Hungary, along with
my family. Quite depressed and without any
thing, I arrived in Boston. A terrible misfortune might have
over taken me had not Herr Jacob Sachs and
his wife exerted all their powers and protected
me and my six small children from destruction. That therefore
is the scene and some what more elaborate picture in
which several characters are portrayed. I transmitted
to Herr Isaac Wise in Cincinnati with the
urgent request that he use it in his German
newspaper. I am enclosing herewith a copy of
my two letters to Herr Wise for your
reading. "And behold the reaping season is
past, the summer is ended, and I have
waited in vain". I sent another letter to
Herr Wise in which I most politely requested

him to return to me my short work, "And behold
the autumn passed, and that which I sought I found not.
And I said, 'To whom among the holy shall i turn?'"
For, had he sent it back empt the work of my hands back
empty handed, I would have kept quiet—but
I am like a man who has not heard and there
are no arguments in his mouth, but now let
me speak and I shall feel relieved. I shall open
my lips and thou shalt answer. And let my
master decide between my brother and your brother
and settle the matter between us. As to you,
Isaac Laban (Wise), listen to my words, I will
not be partial to any man, nor call you by a
man's name, for according to your name such
is your praise*. Let your own mouth condemn
you and not I. And your lips give testimony
against you. Admit in front of the people
whether you have done this...
...or
that you are partial to princes, and if you say,
"Did this man come to dwell and raised himself
to the dignity of Judges", in this you are wrong,
for the former is justified in argument. But
admit that this is a grievous sin, that you
have placed your trust in gold, and had not...
etc, etc

*The reference, I suppose, is to Labon and his
characteristics.

Here follow the two letters which I sent to
Herr Wise, and please include them with
my entire correspondence in your well-known
Occident. Devotedly yours, Kalman Frischman

My address—Karl Frischman, Elliott
Street, No. 101, Boston.
Addressed to I. Wise, Honored Sir:-

Permit me a very urgent wish—to appear
before you. I am encouraged by the thought
that your very kindly disposition will forgive
this step of mine. Three moons have
passed since I left my fatherland Hungary.
Providence directed my steps to America,
that is to Boston. The bitterness of my
fortune and the suffering of my entire family
was so great that I can barely describe
it. In a word, nothing was left us. We
were completely without means. We were
starving. I was not afraid of death, nor
of the passing from one type of life into
another. For whoever bethought himself of
earthly life, what he is and what he can be,
whoever has constantly and willingly occupied

himself with such thought, he can
appreciate the comfort which religion
gives to the human spirit. This strength-
ens his mind and heart. Whoever has
implicit trust in God, does not fear
death. In this respect I was quite con-
tent, by but my duty to my family circle
still had to be fulfilled. That is what
tortured me within, and that is how I
stood upon a foreign soil, namely in Boston,
wringing my hands and calling for help.
And who is it who fr saved me and my
family from annihilation? Herr Joseph
Sachs, the preacher and teacher of the
German congregation in Boston. Yes, this
sympathetic friend of humanity is the
one who rescued my family. To this
kindly man I therefore feel myself
completed indebted to thank openly for his noble action.
"Therefore,' said I, 'I shall go to commune
with Isaac, to bring the story of my
murmuring lips in the collection of
Isaac, and through Isaac he may

find fruit for himself, and if my hand
makes an error in explaining in dear
language all these occurrences which can
barely be imagined." Etc, etc. ......

He ends the letter with the
request that Wise find him a position
somewhere (despite his inability to
speak the language) and that he print
his elaborate story in his German news-
paper.

2nd letter to Dr. Wise. (in Hebrew, with a
string of quotations from the Bible, begging
him to print his article, or return it.).

Then follows an extract from the article which
he sent to Dr. Wise. It consists of rhymed
lines on the style of the prayers in the Ashke-
nazic holiday prayer book, with indirect
references to Biblical heroes and ex-
pressions; also an acrostic poem with
the name of Joseph.
